displayed_text: Family Member: That’s fine. Doctor: And if I have that, uh, if they say that, yes, we can go ahead, we’ll let you know and we’ll have them come back to do all the consenting and all of that procedure. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: If, however, they say, not right now, it’s too much, if it’s a week or two, I’m okay with waiting. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: If it’s going to be a month or more, I don’t think then we should wait. We should look into other things. Family Member: Try something else. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Makes sense? Patient: Okay. Family Member: We stand, we stand in agreement with you.

Patient: Right. Doctor: You know you have a toddler you don't want to- Family Member 1: Well, can he be around? Doctor: - and they just get into it. Family Member 1: Can he still baby sit for A___ when he’s on this medicine? Because we do split shifts. Doctor: So yeah, so that that's a little bit of the hard part. Not so much for you to her, but for her to you. Because if they're their little ones are germy they're just one giant viral bacterial fest, because that's what they they do and they pick up everything. You would be a bit compromised from that. Family Member 1: Could he wear a mask if he wanted? Doctor: He could but just it's challenging to do that because you're kind of have the baby right here. You’re hugging her. Patient: Uh I don’t think Family Member 1: She’s two years old. He lifts her up the crib. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: But we're worried can she get cancer from him? Like from being around him? Doctor: No, she can't get sick from him.

Patient: I can’t cough. Doctor: No, no I’m not uh doing it to hurt you. Patient: Oooh. (inaudible) Doctor: Yeah. Patient: It would be sore and like I told the doctor. Doctor: Um hmm. Patient: I have never, in twenty something years man, I could drink a beer, I have, I have been with my family on holidays and drunk liquor Hennesy like going crazy and I’d never get one to throw up or got sick or something like that. I just went to sleep, but now I I I have… Doctor: Now what happens when you drink? Patient: I throwed up three times man. And I haven’t told and I don’t know if it was blood because I’ve been probably because the light was kind of dim, but it was like red and then it could have been the food I was eating. Doctor: When did you throw up? Patient: About, about maybe uh the chemo now I have diarrhea like two three weeks after. Doctor: Right. When did you throw up is what I’m asking. Patient: Same day I had chemo.

Patient: No. Doctor: Okay. How’s your bowels been? Patient: Okay. Doctor: So slow? That’s what you told me last time. Patient: Yeah, but, you know. Doctor: Still moving daily? Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: How’s your hot flashes? Patient: They come out all the time. (Laughs) Doctor: And urine. Any trouble passing your water? Patient: Uh-uh. Doctor: Okay. And they didn’t keep you in the hospital. Anything new since I saw you a couple of weeks ago that you want to tell me about?

Family Member: Yeah I thought eliminate something that doesn’t irritate. Doctor: Okay Patient: My D three. All my D three and all my vitamins. Doctor: Oh, yes. Did you feel better? Patient: Everything. Um, well, I’m feeling better now but I think I’m feeling better because my stomach- Doctor: Yeah. Well you’re away now more time away from radiation. Patient: Exactly. Doctor: So you know radiation is tough. It helps the pain but it’s always something for something, Patient: Yeah. Doctor: not something for nothing, so there’s some side effects there. And you got a lot of radiation. Patient: So the question there being then probably safe to go back on the supplements? Doctor: Yes. Family Member: On some of them. I would gradually reintroduce them if I was you.

Patient: Okay. When do you get a bone scan, yearly? Doctor: Yeah. Depending on how you do. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. So today all you had was a CAT scan or did you have both? Patient: Yes. Yes. No. Just a scan. Doctor: Oh. So you didn’t go to D___, then? Patient: Oh, no. I saw what you said, yeah. Family Member: He went here. Doctor: Oh. You went here? Patient: Yeah. I misunderstood. Yes. Doctor: Okay. I didn’t realize, okay. Patient: Well, last time I got the bone scan in D___.

Patient: Alright. So, so, so say we start the trial, okay? Doctor: Mm, hmm. Patient: How many pills is what I gotta take and whatnot to start? Doctor: I gotta check. I forget. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I don’t think it’s – Patient: When do you, when do you wanna start the trial? Doctor: You already got your scan. We start the biopsy. We go. No, no time wasted. Patient: Well I got – I got to do the biopsy? Doctor: Yes! Patient: What the hell, doc? Doctor: Don’t look at me! It’s science! You’re contributing!

Patient: Yeah, I’ll just stick with the prednisone. Doctor: Okay. And you can definitely try cutting back on the dose okay because as you saw in the scans, remember last time I had given you a slight inkling that it was heading starting to grow back? Patient: Yes. Doctor: And when we did the recent scans are showing a continued slight increase. So it’s a small increase, the bone scan is still completely okay and so you do not have the spread to the bone that we can see. Patient: Yeah, right, right. Doctor: Uh because of that I think we should stop this treatment. Okay because you’ve sort of gotten the benefit you’re going to get out of it and it may be time to move on to other treatment. Now in terms of other treatments what to go to next? And uh there is a medication that is something called Niraparib okay. And it’s sort of this family of medications called barhabiters. And the way they work is if your cancer expresses certain specific mutations, they it’s likely to be effective. So if you treat everybody with your kind of prostate cancer on this medication, the chances of it working were wherever fifty to twenty percent, so pretty low. When we looked at just the people with those mutations that were expressed in the cancer, then the response went up to seventy eighty percent. So what we’re doing… Family Member: For prostate? Doctor: So what we’re doing – yes, yeah, within prostate cancer. So what we’re doing now is what we’re proposing is that we screen your uh blood, it’s a blood test, that to look for any of those eight genes or mutations that if your cancer has those then I would recommend going on this particular study which gives you these medications which are pills that you would take and we’d monitor you to see if it’s likely to be helpful. Family Member: Is it a type of chemo? Doctor: It is not. It is something called parp… so more like what we call targeted therapy. Okay but it’s different from the immune therapy that you were having. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And I think it has a pretty good shot at working like I said if you had one of those mutations.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: The only place they run into problems is if somebody comes with you know five-hundred things in the bowel, and we’re putting this radiation in cancer, in terms of next to the bone cells, those people mostly get bone marrow problems. But in regard to you, I would expect probably not from the bone marrow. Family Member: Can you get him in this? Doctor: Well the German thing is you know unfortunately you’d have to pay for it. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So it’s not a study. Family Member: Right. Doctor: They’re just taking it as uh pay as you go. Uh so we’ve talked before, and I know you have the means to do it. Uh they, so, I’d, I’d work with a group. There’s a group in Heidelberg, Germany, and there’s a group in a place called Bad Berka, which is, I could show it to you on a map, but it’s, it’s outside of Frankfurt. Patient: Um huh.. Doctor: It’s near, it’s in East Germany. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh those two groups have the biggest experience. The guy I know very well is in Bad Berka. Uh I think both groups though will take referrals, and then they take over and make the arrangements for folks to come, put you up, all the things. And the number they quoted me is about fifty-thousand bucks to do it. Um which by American standards, is incredibly cheap, but because you can’t get, take advantage of health insurance, you know.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um. I’m gonna put the prescription for the enzalutamide in our pharmacy, and they’re gonna do all the work behind the scenes to find out how much it’s gonna cost ya. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Put in the grants and all that other stuff for ya, so that we can get it. Once we know it’s a go, that’s when R_ and I will be back in touch about that. Okay? But you can always back out and say, “This doesn’t make sense. I’m not ready. He’s crazy. We’re not going back to Baltimore.” All of that. Okay? Something bad could happen. You could get in a lot of pain, and they got to treat you right then and there, and this will, will slip past you. Okay? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But I hope that doesn’t happen. Patient: And even, even this treatment – is successful or just extend me for – Doctor: Yeah, I mean other diseases we’ve had people who, uh, their cancer doesn’t come back. Okay? But we haven’t seen that in prostate cancer. Patient: Ahhh. Doctor: Okay? Patient: I mean, I didn’t even have a prostate when I got it. How did that happen? Family Member: I don’t think they always got it all out of your lymph nodes when they first harvested it. Doctor: Yeah. It had to be there before they did the surgery.

Healthcare Professional: Yeah Doctor: Okay. So then I- for now I'm going to stay with the same dose. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I think the next step before this tearing and everything, and we are getting up there in number of cycles you've gotten, Patient: Correct. Doctor: we may need to consider cutting back on the dose or-- Patient: Okay. Doctor: --taking a break for a longer time or- Family Member: He needs a break. Doctor: --whatever. Patient: 'Cause that break really was nice, it worked out well the way it--I mean-- Doctor: I think your last time you really looked, uh, tired out.

Patient: Okay. Alright. Doctor: So, this is a prescription for Norco so theres, you know, it’s five slash three-twenty-five Patient: Okay. Doctor: so I think we provided one hundred twenty Patient: Right. Doctor: so we don’t want you to run out. Obviously, if you take all one hundred twenty at one time you’re in trouble so don’t do that. Patient: I would say, yeah I’m not gonna do that. Doctor: You take one or two at a time. Family Member: Call Monday and say we need more. Patient: Yeah, right. Yeah, this stuff’s really good. Doctor: The next thing you know the DEA is going H____ I hear you’re off this. No, not me. And I think here we have to, let me see, how do we get this from you? So, this is just a lot of the, sort of like a list and a contract if you will. Sort of these are all the risks, this is why we’re doing it. So, every time we prescribe opiates we have to do that now. Patient: I have to sign this? Doctor: Yeah.

Healthcare Professional: this shows up. Doctor: Um… Healthcare Professional: This is Doctor: Let’s order. Healthcare Professional: Okay. Doctor: So we'll see if that works. Okay? Patient: Mhm. Doctor: And then, once we know it's scheduled, we'll see you shortly thereafter to go to the results. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And um. Big decision. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Any questions that brings up? Patient: No, I think this is in parallel to what we've been talking about, which is let's see what we're dealing with. Let's let it grow. Let's let it- how fast is it growing? Where is it growing? We would find out, but I didn't think we would find this huge mass somewhere because it's just hasn't shown itself that way. So I think this makes sense. We'll add in just bloodwork. Oh, yeah, I didn’t know if I was supposed to have one.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, but it can be effective against the cancer. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, I personally tend to use chemotherapy later than most of the people. Uh, and part of the reason for that is because we have a lot of trials which, you know, we believe in, of course, because they’re our studies. And we have best of interest in them. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And we have laboratory research on those things, so we are excited, you know – Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - to go to humans, human trials, but, uh, unless, unless your pain is getting substantially worse, in which case I would strongly encourage you to do the chemo, because that’s going to work the fastest. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Unless the pain is clearly getting worse, and if I feel that we have like a window of opportunity, where, you know, maybe the hasn’t worked but your cancer is not bad enough that you need chemotherapy right this second, then that might be like an opportunity to try a second trial. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But if I truly believe that this pain is escalating or you’re having, you know, more bad days than good days, or, you know, you’re really not able to sleep for more than like an hour at a time because you’re waking up because of back pain, those types of things would certainly lead me towards maybe chemotherapy as the next step, and perhaps reserving that clinical trial for after the chemotherapy is over.

Patient: Well, we sold the house. Doctor: Okay. Congratulations. I think. (Laughs) Patient: Sold the house and we haven’t… Family Member: We’re living at my dad’s without a stove and refrigerator so we’re eating out all the time. Doctor: That’s it. I’m going to get you people straight now. Right here. Doctor: You’re giving me heartburn. You are. Patient: Yeah, well, this is true. Eating out. Family Member: Well there’s good choices you can make. Doctor: Yeah. (Laughs) Patient: You know and a lot more bad ones. Doctor: That is true. Huh, this makes a lot of sense now. Okay. And when do we expect to leave your dad’s house? Patient: I think we’re supposed to be getting the keys to the house we’re purchasing next week. Doctor: Okay.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian
